text: Mary Lou Clements-Mann (September 17, 1946 - September 2, 1998) was the longtime head of the Division of Vaccine Sciences at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, and is well known for her knowledge and work in HIV and AIDS research.Johns Hopkins Gazette Story about Death of Clements-Mann and her husband She died in the 1998 crash of Swissair Flight 111 with her husband, Jonathan Mann. Clements-Mann graduated from Texas Tech University in 1968 and received her medical degree from the University of Texas in 1972. She also received a doctorate in tropical medicine from the University of London in 1975 and a master's degree in public health, specifically epidemiology, from Johns Hopkins University in 1979. ==Career== Clements-Mann was an assistant professor at the University of Maryland School of Medicine from 1979 to 1985. She was a member of the US Centers for Disease Control Advisory Committee on the Children's Vaccine Initiative and the World Health Organization's steering committee for HIV vaccine development. ==Personal life== Clements-Mann married Jonathan Mann in December 1996. == References == Category:1946 births Category:1998 deaths Category:Accidental deaths in Nova Scotia Category:Alumni of the University of London Category:American biologists Category:American public health doctors Category:HIV/AIDS researchers Category:Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health alumni Category:Johns Hopkins University faculty Category:People from Longview, Texas Category:People who died at sea Category:Texas Tech University alumni Category:University of Maryland, Baltimore faculty Category:University of Texas alumni Category:Victims of aviation accidents or incidents in Canada Category:Victims of aviation accidents or incidents in 1998 Category:World Health Organization officials Category:20th-century American physicians Category:American officials of the United Nations Category:20th-century biologists Category:People from Columbia, Maryland
title: Mary Lou Clements-Mann
